items.label: rem-asymmetric-coupling
items.title: Asymmetric Coupling
items.content:
404: :label: rem-asymmetric-coupling
405: 
406: The coupling is **asymmetric**: the matching distribution $P(M | S_1)$ depends only on swarm $S_1$, not $S_2$. This is standard practice in coupling arguments and simplifies analysis while maintaining sufficient correlation for contraction.
items.raw_directive:
401: :::
402: 
403: :::{prf:remark} Asymmetric Coupling
404: :label: rem-asymmetric-coupling
405: 
406: The coupling is **asymmetric**: the matching distribution $P(M | S_1)$ depends only on swarm $S_1$, not $S_2$. This is standard practice in coupling arguments and simplifies analysis while maintaining sufficient correlation for contraction.
407:

items.label: rem-jitter-cancellation
items.title: Jitter Cancellation in Clone-Clone Case
items.content:
412: :label: rem-jitter-cancellation
413: 
414: The most powerful feature of this coupling is **jitter cancellation**. If walker $i$ clones in **both** swarms (which happens in Case A with consistent fitness ordering), then:
415: 
416: $$
417: \|x'_{1,i} - x'_{2,i}\|^2 = \|(x_{1,\pi(i)} + \zeta_i) - (x_{2,\pi(i)} + \zeta_i)\|^2 = \|x_{1,\pi(i)} - x_{2,\pi(i)}\|^2
418: $$
419: 
420: The jitter **cancels exactly** due to synchronization! This is the strongest form of contraction.
items.raw_directive:
409: :::
410: 
411: :::{prf:remark} Jitter Cancellation in Clone-Clone Case
412: :label: rem-jitter-cancellation
413: 
414: The most powerful feature of this coupling is **jitter cancellation**. If walker $i$ clones in **both** swarms (which happens in Case A with consistent fitness ordering), then:
415: 
416: $$
417: \|x'_{1,i} - x'_{2,i}\|^2 = \|(x_{1,\pi(i)} + \zeta_i) - (x_{2,\pi(i)} + \zeta_i)\|^2 = \|x_{1,\pi(i)} - x_{2,\pi(i)}\|^2
418: $$
419: 
420: The jitter **cancels exactly** due to synchronization! This is the strongest form of contraction.
421:

items.label: rem-coupling-sufficiency
items.title: Synchronous Coupling Sufficiency
items.content:
428: :label: rem-coupling-sufficiency
429: 
430: The synchronous coupling {prf:ref}`def-synchronous-cloning-coupling` provides sufficient correlation to prove Wasserstein-2 contraction. By using shared randomness (matching $M$, thresholds $T_i$, jitter $\zeta_i$), the coupling eliminates extrinsic variance sources and maximizes correlation between paired walkers.
431: 
432: **Key Properties:**
433: 1. **Jitter cancellation**: When both walkers clone, the shared jitter $\zeta_i$ cancels exactly
434: 2. **Maximum correlation**: Using the same matching and thresholds minimizes $\mathbb{E}[\sum_i \|x'_{1,i} - x'_{2,i}\|^2]$
435: 3. **Tractable analysis**: The synchronous structure allows explicit calculation of contraction factors
items.raw_directive:
425: ### 1.3. Coupling Properties
426: 
427: :::{prf:remark} Synchronous Coupling Sufficiency
428: :label: rem-coupling-sufficiency
429: 
430: The synchronous coupling {prf:ref}`def-synchronous-cloning-coupling` provides sufficient correlation to prove Wasserstein-2 contraction. By using shared randomness (matching $M$, thresholds $T_i$, jitter $\zeta_i$), the coupling eliminates extrinsic variance sources and maximizes correlation between paired walkers.
431: 
432: **Key Properties:**
433: 1. **Jitter cancellation**: When both walkers clone, the shared jitter $\zeta_i$ cancels exactly
434: 2. **Maximum correlation**: Using the same matching and thresholds minimizes $\mathbb{E}[\sum_i \|x'_{1,i} - x'_{2,i}\|^2]$
435: 3. **Tractable analysis**: The synchronous structure allows explicit calculation of contraction factors
436:

items.label: rem-valley-depth
items.title: Quantitative Bounds
items.content:
522: :label: rem-valley-depth
523: 
524: For swarms at distance $L > D_{\min}$, the valley depth can be bounded using framework parameters:
525: 
526: $$
527: \Delta_{\text{valley}} \geq \kappa_{\text{valley}}(\varepsilon) \cdot V_{\text{pot,min}}
528: $$
items.raw_directive:
519: :::
520: 
521: :::{prf:remark} Quantitative Bounds
522: :label: rem-valley-depth
523: 
524: For swarms at distance $L > D_{\min}$, the valley depth can be bounded using framework parameters:
525: 
526: $$
527: \Delta_{\text{valley}} \geq \kappa_{\text{valley}}(\varepsilon) \cdot V_{\text{pot,min}}
528: $$
529:

items.label: rem-asymptotic-exactness
items.title: Asymptotic Exactness
items.content:
755: :label: rem-asymptotic-exactness
756: 
757: For $L \to \infty$, the survival probability of wrong-side outliers vanishes exponentially:
758: 
759: $$
760: \mathbb{P}(\text{survive} \mid M_1) \leq e^{-c L/R_H}
761: $$
items.raw_directive:
752: :::
753: 
754: :::{prf:remark} Asymptotic Exactness
755: :label: rem-asymptotic-exactness
756: 
757: For $L \to \infty$, the survival probability of wrong-side outliers vanishes exponentially:
758: 
759: $$
760: \mathbb{P}(\text{survive} \mid M_1) \leq e^{-c L/R_H}
761: $$
762:

items.label: rem-emergent-property
items.title: Why This is Emergent, Not Axiomatic
items.content:
767: :label: rem-emergent-property
768: 
769: The Outlier Alignment property is **not** an additional axiom. It is a **consequence** of:
770: 1. The Confining Potential axiom (Axiom 2.1.1)
771: 2. The Environmental Richness axiom (Axiom 4.1.1)
772: 3. The cloning operator definition (survival $\propto$ fitness)
773: 4. The Geometric Partition structure (Keystone Principle)
items.raw_directive:
764: :::
765: 
766: :::{prf:remark} Why This is Emergent, Not Axiomatic
767: :label: rem-emergent-property
768: 
769: The Outlier Alignment property is **not** an additional axiom. It is a **consequence** of:
770: 1. The Confining Potential axiom (Axiom 2.1.1)
771: 2. The Environmental Richness axiom (Axiom 4.1.1)
772: 3. The cloning operator definition (survival $\propto$ fitness)
773: 4. The Geometric Partition structure (Keystone Principle)
774:

items.label: rem-projection-implies-quadratic
items.title: Implications for Contraction
items.content:
1333: :label: rem-projection-implies-quadratic
1334: 
1335: This lemma shows that the "linear" terms like $\eta R_H L$ from the geometric bound are actually quadratic when $R_H \sim L$:
1336: 
1337: $$
1338: \eta R_H L \geq \eta (c_0 L - c_1) L = \eta c_0 L^2 - \eta c_1 L \sim O(L^2)
1339: $$
items.raw_directive:
1330: :::
1331: 
1332: :::{prf:remark} Implications for Contraction
1333: :label: rem-projection-implies-quadratic
1334: 
1335: This lemma shows that the "linear" terms like $\eta R_H L$ from the geometric bound are actually quadratic when $R_H \sim L$:
1336: 
1337: $$
1338: \eta R_H L \geq \eta (c_0 L - c_1) L = \eta c_0 L^2 - \eta c_1 L \sim O(L^2)
1339: $$
1340:

items.label: rem-linear-vs-quadratic
items.title: Comparison with Linear Bound
items.content:
1412: :label: rem-linear-vs-quadratic
1413: 
1414: The previous analysis derived $D_{ii} - D_{ji} \geq \eta R_H L$, which appeared linear in $L$. However:
1415: 
1416: 1. **Via Exact Identity:** We now have $D_{ii} - D_{ji} \approx L^2$ directly
1417: 2. **Via High-Error Projection:** $R_H \geq c_0 L$, so $\eta R_H L \geq \eta c_0 L^2$
items.raw_directive:
1409: :::
1410: 
1411: :::{prf:remark} Comparison with Linear Bound
1412: :label: rem-linear-vs-quadratic
1413: 
1414: The previous analysis derived $D_{ii} - D_{ji} \geq \eta R_H L$, which appeared linear in $L$. However:
1415: 
1416: 1. **Via Exact Identity:** We now have $D_{ii} - D_{ji} \approx L^2$ directly
1417: 2. **Via High-Error Projection:** $R_H \geq c_0 L$, so $\eta R_H L \geq \eta c_0 L^2$
1418:

items.label: rem-case-b-frequency
items.title: Typical Values
items.content:
1524: :label: rem-case-b-frequency
1525: 
1526: From the Keystone Principle analysis in [03_cloning.md](03_cloning.md):
1527: - $f_{UH}(\varepsilon) \geq 0.1$ (at least 10% unfit-high-error overlap)
1528: - $q_{\min}(\varepsilon) \geq 0.01$ (matching has at least 1% probability for any configuration)
1529: 
1530: Therefore:
1531: $$
1532: \mathbb{P}(\text{Case B}) \gtrsim 0.001
1533: $$
items.raw_directive:
1521: :::
